newsitem.title: CHINA: China says textile spat could hit Sino-U.S. trade.
newsitem.headline: China says textile spat could hit Sino-U.S. trade.

text.p: China told the United States on Sunday to step back from tough action in a dispute over illegal transshipments of Chinese textiles, saying if Washington cut textile import quotas it risked hurting overall trade ties.

"Chinese officials and textiles exporters are urging the United States to withdraw its decision to slash export quotas on Chinese textiles," the official China Daily Business Weekly said in a front page article.
"Such a practice is unfair and could affect not only Chinese textile exports but (also) overall Sino-U.S. trade ties," the newspaper said.
Washington earlier this month announced punitive charges against China's 1996 textile and apparel quotas, citing Chinese textile transshipments in violation of a 1994 trade agreement.
An investigation by the U.S. Customs Service accused China of working aggressively to circumvent the agreement.
Beijing has denied the allegation and urged the United States to rescind the punitive action, which is expected to cost China about $19 million, or risk retaliatory action.

The U.S. charges were unacceptable and Washington had failed to provide clear evidence of the alleged transshipments, the Business Weekly quoted Li Dongsheng, a department head at the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, as saying.
Innocent Chinese exporters should not be blamed when foreign businessmen carried out illegal shipments to the United States, he said.

Washington's moves to limit Chinese textile imports carried a strong tint of trade protectionism and U.S. textiles importers and consumers were likely to suffer, the newspaper quoted officials of the China National Textile Council as saying.
In February 1995 and in June this year, Beijing and Washington narrowly avoided what would have been multibillion dollar trade wars over widespread copyright piracy in China.
Both sides say ties have warmed in recent months, helped by a string of high-level meetings.
